hints_html:
Use the limit law for quotients.

Let

\[\begin{aligned} a=\lim_{x\to\infty} f(x).\end{aligned}\]

Then compute

\[\begin{aligned} \lim_{x\to\infty}\frac{g(x)}{f(x)-1}.\end{aligned}\]

This is equal to 3. What can you conclude?
hints_latex: Use the limit law for quotients.

Let

\begin{align*}
a=\lim_{x\to\infty} f(x).
\end{align*} Then compute

\begin{align*}
\lim_{x\to\infty}\frac{g(x)}{f(x)-1}.
\end{align*} This is equal to 3. What can
you conclude?
hints_raw:
Use the limit law for quotients.
Let 
:<math>a=\lim_{x\to\infty} f(x).</math>
Then compute 
:<math>
\lim_{x\to\infty}\frac{g(x)}{f(x)-1}.
</math>
This is equal to 3.  What can you conclude?
question: 1 (b)
sols_html:
Since the numerator, \(g(x),\) approaches 6 as \(x\to\infty,\) the denominator must approach 2 in order for the fraction to approach 3. Hence,

\[\begin{aligned} \lim_{x\to\infty}f(x)=3.\end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
Since the numerator, <math>g(x),</math> approaches 6 as <math>x\to\infty,</math> the denominator must approach 2 in order for the fraction to approach 3.  Hence,
:<math>
\lim_{x\to\infty}f(x)=3.
</math>
